Subject: Re: [junit] Best practice - should I fake, or depend on real world
 objects?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=135183696
X-Yahoo-Profile: jpschertz
X-eGroups-Approved-By: nails762 <jbrains@...> via web; 09 Apr 2004 16:23:52 -0000
X-eGroups-Remote-IP: 66.218.66.101

It really depends what you're trying to test.  I ended up doing both for
my current project.  I'm working on a client/server app so I ended up
essentially faking the data from the server that the client reads in order
to test the client component by itself.  In addition, I added integration
tests that have the client accessing the server and parsing its output
live.  The two sets of tests tell me different things.  If I only had the
integration tests, it would be more difficult to tell where the problem is
coming from although not impossible.

Mocking up the real world objects carries some risk, of course.  Namely
that the real world objects will change before you can update the mock
ones, and then your tests are out of date and possibly giving false
indicators of success.  Or that the mock implementations will have bugs
and also give false indicators of success or failure.

In reality, whether to do one or both depends on how much time you have
and which will provide greater value.  Don't forget the downstream
maintenance consequences.  That is project-dependent and only you can
answer that.

Jeremy

--
Jeremy Schertzinger
